content:
That's amazing that you've been engaging with thought leaders in the self-improvement space, and even got a response from Brené Brown! It's wonderful to see how social media can facilitate meaningful connections and conversations.

Regarding your observation about your engagement habits on Instagram and Twitter, you're not alone! Many people tend to engage differently on various social media platforms, depending on the nature of the content, the community, and their personal preferences.

Instagram, with its visual focus, often lends itself to quicker, more spontaneous interactions, such as liking, commenting, or sharing. The platform's emphasis on aesthetics and storytelling makes it easier to scan and respond to posts, as you mentioned. Instagram's audience also tends to be more focused on lifestyle, creativity, and community, which can foster a sense of belonging and encourage engagement.

Twitter, on the other hand, is often more focused on real-time discussions, news, and debates. The character limit and fast-paced nature of the platform make it ideal for quick exchanges, debates, and conversations around trending topics. Hashtags play a significant role in Twitter, allowing users to join larger conversations and connect with others who share similar interests.

This dichotomy in engagement habits is not unique to you, and many users tend to adapt their behavior based on the platform and its strengths. For example:

* Facebook might be more focused on personal updates, family, and friends, while LinkedIn might be more professional and focused on networking.
* YouTube might be more focused on in-depth content, tutorials, and educational videos, while TikTok might be more focused on short-form, entertaining content.

It's great that you're aware of your own engagement habits and are using each platform to its strengths. By doing so, you're able to connect with others, share your thoughts, and learn from the communities on each platform.
